Accepted. Forge activated.
Forge active.
I'm busy here. If you need something, go to Gnomus, Klom Stonecutter or Lardoc for more information.
Hiho Player and greetings kid! What brings you here?
I'm the master of the Hall of the Ancients.
The burial chamber of our ancestors. All firstborn of our race are there .. all but Durin.
Ah yes, the first born. He became a higher entity to protect us. His mortal remains were buried at a remote spot.
My name is Isimov Dustbearer, son of Fire and Earth from the Molten Rock.
I can see you received the blessing of the two suns in the suntower near Ab'Dendriel.
Gives us food and shelter, quite useful isn't it?
The last haven for dwarfs. Our last hope for survival.
Etzel, good old Etzel. I was his teacher long time ago. Now he's running a guild ... they grow so fast ... so fast, jawoll.
A world of dangers, a world of wonders.
I think it's the fourth age of the yellow flame, isn't it?
You are too young for quests, jawoll.
Keep your adventurer's stone well.
The gods abandoned us, we abandoned the gods. That's it, no big deal I tell ya, jawoll.
I've seen many of his type come and go. He will fall and somebody else will take his place.
The emperor resides far above us in the upper caves. Sometimes I wonder if it's a good idea that the emperor is that far away from the temple.
Life is easy to understand. First you are born, then you die. Simple stuff, even elves could grasp the concept.
<sighs> A bunch of kids playing war. May the elements help us.
This mountain is as old as the world. The first dwarfs were born here.
Greed for gold can blind your vision for important things.

There are five blessings available in five sacred places: the spiritual shielding, the spark of the phoenix, the embrace of Tibia, the fire of the suns and the wisdom of solitude. Additionally, you can receive the twist of fate here. ...
You can become a citizen of Kazordoon through the power of our ancestors.

It is said that one enhanced blessing, the 'heart of the mountain', has been lost in the icy wastes of Svargrond. Find a nomad far to the west of these barren lands, hiding in the cold there, slightly above ground. ...

It is also said that a mysterious djinn, bound to an existence of slavery, lies buried somewhere beneath the northern Tiquanda jungle. I cannot confirm whether this tale is true but if you find him, you shall also find the 'blood of the mountain'.
Go and buy some.
The life of a dwarf is an eternal struggle. It hardens us and makes us the fine race we are, jawoll.
They worship the elemental forces of the earth.
Are they still around? Well, give them one or two hundred years and they'll be gone, jawoll.
You do not need any healing right now.
Never heard that word. What's a gregor?
Isn't that the kid that took over the Jolly Axeman tavern? Far too young for such a job, but did anyone ask me? No!
How could she marry this Jimbin? I mean, they are kids! Know nothing about life and stuff. Couldn't they wait for at least a hundred years or so?
Bezil and Nezil are typical profiteers, they belong to a fine new breed of dwarfs we've raised, pah.
What a hasty fellow! Can't be healthy to live in such a hurry, jawoll.
He has almost no beard, and he has already forgotten the traditions of his ancestors. Modern techniques... almost like one of these technomancers.
Could become a great warrior one day. Still needs to learn so much.
I'm not sure if I should tell you. After all, you are a human, and not a dwarf. Hmm, probably not. Sorry.
A young and greedy race, but somewhat noble. Sometimes, they remind me of orcs.
Don't know much about this stuff. Find them in my soup sometimes.
They leave us alone, and we leave them alone.
Only another nuisance.
I must admit there have been worse generals in the years before, jawoll.
I don't know anything new.
The greenskins are after everybody. Beware!
They worship the elemental forces of fire.
Just ask in which of the five blessings you are interested in.
You already received my line of the prayer.

The twist of fate will not reduce the death penalty like the other blessings, but instead prevent you from losing your other blessings as well as the amulet of loss, should you wear one. It costs the same as the other blessings. ...
Would you like to receive that protection for a sacrifice of 50000 gold, child?
This is a special blessing I can bestow upon you once you have obtained at least one of the other blessings and which functions a bit differently. ...
It only works when you're killed by other adventurers, which means that at least forty percent of the damage leading to your death was caused by others, not by monsters or the environment. ...
I see you received the spiritual shielding in the whiteflower temple south of Thais.
I can sense that the spark of the phoenix already was given to you by the dwarven priests of earth and fire in Kazordoon.
I can sense that the druids north of Carlin have provided you with the Embrace of Tibia.
I can see you received the blessing of the two suns in the suntower near Ab'Dendriel.
I can sense you already talked to the hermit Eremo on the isle of Cormaya and received this blessing.
Ahhh! When I was a little dwarf, I was on a quest to find it. I was digging up the complete ghostlands and now one thing is sure: It must be somewhere else, jawoll.
Take care, Player!
Just great, another disturbance. Just what I need.
Those good-for-nothing horned monkeys have no better idea than to assault our workers and ruin our mining efforts. Each dead one is a step forward.
What do you mean, you haven't seen any?? They're hard to overlook, big and furry. Something must be wrong with your eyes.
Well, if you can find a giant beaver that's enormous enough for you to jump on, fat human, you're welcome to compete with us.
Ah, speak no more! I know you want to participate in the beaver rodeo this year! Well, I have some more bait to sell, just ask me for a trade.
We mine ore and crystals in the mines around here. On a good day, we even find gold. Now, don't get that greedy look! Stay out of there!
I'm the master of supplies for the imperial mining guild. And as such, as you might have guessed, I am a very busy dwarf, so speak up and speak quickly.
Well, supplies like tools, food or wood.
Unless you're on a mission, I don't know why I should help you acquiring wood. Or what are you suggesting??
Yep! That's us. You're a smart one.
Pah! Speak no more of them treehuggers.
I'm Melfar Rockdriller, master of supplies.
I don't think I have anything you could need. <scratches head> But if you've slain some of them nasty minotaurs - we could definitely use some of their old stuff, especially their horns.
Good bye.
Welcome! What a tragedy! My business was doing well but now these unexpected incidents queered my pitch.
My name is Brodraem Orcbeard.
I am the grave digger of the recently opened Kazordoon crypt. This should be a place to keep a worthy memory to all deceased inhabitants of this town.
Well, I have to make the coffins and sarcophagi my customers want. Their wishes can be very different and sometimes impossible.
First I thought it would be enough to clean the sarcophagi more often. But then some of the floor tiles broke and some columns crumbled. ...
I had so much to do that I had to stop my business. You want me to hire you for investigating the crypt?
It is your decision. Come back if you have changed your mind. Otherwise I have to find someone else. (idle)
Keep up your good work, Player.
Take care!
Hi!

answer: How dare you!
LONG LIVE THE EMPEROR!
MIND YOUR MANNERS, FOREIGNER! To address the emperor greet with his title!
Hi there.
Human society has been polluted by the taint of magic like many of Tibia's civilisations.

Sadly, even my own people distrust us and our technology to some extent. They think we are 'different' and some of the ancients condemn us because we don't align ourselves with the elemental forces. ...
It's not that we don't honour the elements, we do. But we have a different approach to honouring the elements. ...
This difference is the source of the distrust, but despite this, our inventions have become an integral part of dwarven society and we are acknowledged for our accomplishments.
Magic is unreliable, restrictive and hampers progress. ...
I know, you're thinking 'he's just jealous and wants technomancy to get more attention' but it's not only technology that is held back by the quick fixes magic provides - society suffers as well. ...
Consider this. There is a spell for everything so nobody tries to find alternative solutions for their problems - the need for creative thinking disappears and people become lazy. ...

People become trapped by their superstions because they know someone only needs to mutter a few words to turn them into a frog and suddenly, the whole world is full of people putting the evil eye on you. ...
They blame fate for their problems rather than taking responsibility for their own lives. . ...
Of course, some of these arguments could be used against technology, but at least there is skill and thought behind technology, not just some hocus pocus gobbledygook!
Regardless of what those narrowminded spellcasters claim, technomancy is a science in its own right. It is much more precise than dabbling in magic and incomprehensible forces. ...
And, what's more, it's based on logical thinking - not some freaky talent you have to be born with. ...
Of course I understand why you humans prefer to rely on chance and childrens' rhymes without having any true understanding of what you are doing. ...
As a technomancer, you can at least work out your mistakes because they are based on logic, even if the mistake you have made is likely to have blown someone up . ...
That does not make our interaction with dwarven society an easy one, but we get along well enough.
Dwarfs are a race apart - a unique race. ...

I can fully understand the fact that other races such as humans and ... um ... elves and orcs and ... um ... cyclopes and ... hm ... flies and so on are in awe of us. But for us, our genius is an everyday fact of life. ...
Nevermind, human. Your inferiority is not your fault. Not every race can be as gifted as we are. Not that I mean to be rude or anything.

Hah! Elves! So blinded by their attachment to magic. If you were to ask them how a bow and arrow worked, they would probably tell you the spirits of the air carry their arrows to the hearts of their enemies! ...
They don't have the slightest idea of mechanics or physics.

Yes, yes. Fascinating issue. Hmm. Let's see .. I don't know too much about golems themselves, but I have a good idea about the mechanics involved. After researching some material that Telas sent me I was able to work out some crucial information. ...
Using the information I have put together, Telas should be able to pass on the specs to the blacksmiths. At least he can get the mechanical components organised.
Ah, yes, Telas. Quite smart for someone that tall.
Oh please. If you don't know what mechanics are about, go and find another dwarf who has a century to spare to explain it all to you. ...
I have more important things to do than show a human what a spanner is for.
From what has reached my ears it's quite a sight. I am not a big traveller so I don't really have an opinion and wouldn't be able to tell the difference between the truth and exaggeration. ...
But the word is that these Yalahari don't care much about keeping their machines in a good shape. What are they thinking of? Don't they know that a machine must be tended and cared for? ...
There is something odd going on in that city, I tell you. No-one who builds such wonders grows that careless.

Strange people, but that's no surprise considering they are not dwarfs. They had a good hand for technology though. Unfortunately they mixed it with magic which to my mind is as bad as watering beer, a crime! ...
Still, there is certainly a lot to be learned from their inventions. But they keep their secrets well guarded. I can understand and appreciate that.

What kind of a silly question is that? But fine: a machine is something that can do everything you can but twice as efficiently. And no, despite these qualities it doesn't have a tail, fur and above all, it doesn't eat bananas!
My greatest invention was the improved lift system that we used on the farms. It was by far more efficient and fast than the old ones. And what did those technophobic dwarfs go and do? ...
They made me a lift boy out of gratitude! They insisted that I had to operate it to guarantee its safety. What a joy I tell you! 'Lift me up Scutty' the whole stupid day! ...
Great! It took years for them to get used to the lift and let me move on to my other projects.
As you can see, I'm the tooth fairy. I collect children's teeth and wear a tutu and fly. ...

Ask a stupid question, get a stupid answer! What do you think all these machines are for? Why are my hands black with machine oil and why am I wearing a tool belt? No, I am not an unhygienic tooth fairy. ...
I am a technomancer! Master of machines and mechanics!
Scutty is the name. I'll spare you the part that only dwarfs can pronounce.
Yeah, bye.
Welcome to the Jolly Axeman, have a good time and some drinks, Player!
I can offer you beer... or water if you are sick. If you'd like to see my offers, ask me for a trade.
Take a look, but not a sip before you paid.
I am Jimbin Luckythroat, son of Earth, from the Molten Rock.
I'm running the Jolly Axeman together with my wife Maryza.
She's a fine cook; likes it bloody, though. Humans call her Bloody Mary, but don't mention that to her if you're smart.
Ask my wife Maryza for food.
Silly town. Alcohol is forbidden there and elves visit this town quite often, which certainly suggests nothing good about a town, jawoll.
Bah! Humans, can't stand a drink, jawoll.
Hah! He never dares to trespass our realm.
Actually, I believe it's more than a tavern tale.
Oh well, many hidden places of ancient times appear seemingly out of nowhere in these times.
It is about 5:12 am.
I supply the army with dwarfish beer to keep morale high.
The cookbook? It belongs to Maryza. I think she has a few copies for sale.
The general is a fine man. Can drink as much as he wants and still is sober.
The king orders huge amounts of mushroom beer for festivities.

Stories of their mostly made-up exploits and lies lured some into their embrace, but it was not until the blight that they became popular and a threat thanks to their leader, Jarok Bilespit.

Well, Jarok Bilespit was a mercenary. He did many questionable things for money. Especially dealing with non-dwarfs, although he usually was the first to express their disgust for them, when not taking their money, of course. ...

He gathered around him a number of drunkards and bullies of the worst sort, and founded the Axes of Vengeance fellowship, which was rather his private gang than a true fellowship. ... Emperor Kruzak: They were usually travelling on contract, doing questionable missions and only returned to Kazordoon to boast about their made-up exploits and to spend their ill-begotten money with both hands. ...
This impressed certain people and gained him an undeserved reputation as a daring hero. ...

Though no week they were in town passed without one of them getting imprisoned for brawls, threats and destruction of property, especially younger dwarfs thought it would be cool to be one of them, and if not respected, then at least be feared. ...

When the blight struck, his easy explanations and pointless accusations stroke a cord in the minds of several individuals. I admit we did not see this coming and let him spread his phrases in the city. ...
We had other things to do and did not want more unrest by arresting some popular figure. With our attention elsewhere, Bilespit took advantage of the desperate and lured them into his ranks. ...
He was never the subtle type though, so it became quite clear what unspeakable treason he planed. ...

When he led his bunch of mercenaries and several drunks as some kind of meat-shield to dethrone me, we were prepared. We planned to take Bilespit down first to minimize casualties, but things got out of hand and there were many deaths on both sides. ...

With the order to keep presumably innocent casualties low, my guards fought very restricted, which could have led to their losing the battle. So we had to change orders to reduce our own casualties, and the fight turned very bloody and nasty. ...
Rumours spread through the city and others who thought they sympathized with Bilespit's cause joined the battles. ...
Still, we tried to keep casualties low; and as soon as we took certain strategic positions and gained the upper hand, most of the rebellious forces escaped. ...
Now they are hiding in the mine: Most of those mines are old and depleted of ore. They are overrun by all sorts of creatures such as the Lost. ...

As for the rest of the rules, the most important thing to know is that there is a time limit for each fight as well as right before a match. ...
After the fight has been initiated by giving me the necessary details, a timer will be started. ...
A fight is won if either only one player is left or only one team (at least one member of the team still standing at the end of a fight). ...
The fight will be canceled if the predetermined number of players for a fight does not show up in the anteroom. ...
If a fight is in progress but takes too long or no clear winner could be termined (this includes team fights were at least one member of both teams is still standing), it will be canceled as well.
Every premium player can participate in the arena. To initiate the arena, just talk to me and tell me if you want to play last man standing or a team deathmatch. ...
If the arena is not currently occupied you will then be able to tell me how many players will take part. You can also create one-on-one matches in both modes by adding only 2 players. ...
If you opted for a team deathmatch, you will have to select the members for each team by telling me the correct names. ...
After that you will have to specify the stakes for the fight.
I can give you information on stakes or how the prize money will be split in last man standing or team deathmatch mode.
Depending on the stake the initiating player has determined for a fight, each player will have to have this amount of gold on his or her bank account to take part. ...
As soon as the match starts (not while waiting or by entering an anteroom after the fight has been initiated), the money will be deducted. ...
Together, these stakes will add to the prize money, which will either go to the single winner of a last man standing fight or to the winning team in a team deathmatch. ...
If the match cannot be finished within the time limit, this money will be lost!

In a team deathmatch this money is split evenly among each player of the winning team (please note that the final share will be rounded down in case of uneven splits). ...
If a winning team consists of 5 players and only 2 members are still standing at the end of a fight, the money will still be split among all 5 members of the team.

Evil lurks everywhere. It only takes some ignorant or cowardly people to turn their heads away once too often for it to spread its ugly seeds. I, however, am constantly vigilant and always prepared. ...
I hunt out the signs of evil everywhere. Even in the face of scorn and ridicule, I will not hide my head in the sand and I will be ready to fight!
Ignorance is evil's most potent ally. The servants of evil are plotting to keep us ignorant and poke ridicule at those who come too close to the truth.
It is my calling to root out evil in all its forms and uphold the vigilant fight. It is a lonely fight, an unending fight, but someone has to do it! ...
I scour ancient texts and collect rumours in taverns in order to track the machinations of evil. ...
Often odd occurrences are overlooked by the public as strange coincidences or fate, but those who know what to look for see the footprints of evil in history.

When I found that ancient text, warning of the Isle of Evil, I tried to tell the world about it. But the forces of evil discovered my plans! They made people assume it was just another tale for children. ...

THEY distributed a book of children's bedtime stories with a copy of the text in it to undermine my message! Their despicable ruse worked and they made a laughing stock of me! Of course I knew it was a plot to discredit me. ...
On the other hand, it was obvious that THEY now knew about me and the text I possessed. I went into hiding in fear of my life! THEY have tried to assassinate me! I must be constantly vigilant!
You'll find it in one of my chests. It's only a copy of course. The original is safely hidden! As much as THEY claim it's only a children's tale I know it's the truth.
Bah, THEY forged a children's book that made my source material look like some part of it. Of course it is an evil plot to prevent me from locating the isle and slaying its dark master. ...
Or rather, sending some other hero who will fight the ultimate evil in its own lair on my behalf. Someone has to stay and fight the fight on the mainland, of course.
Evil follows a distinct pattern. It is nasty, plans to rule the world, discredits its enemies, is fond of cunning death traps and rambling monologues, ...
it can only be vanquished by someone who completes a series of quests for some odd quest giver and it loves to have a lair, usually some sort of dungeon.
Scientists have no idea why the servants of evil are so fond of dungeons. But every evil mastermind worth his salt strives to own one. It is where it accomodates its minions and hoards its treasures.

Evil masterminds are served by all kinds of lesser evil beings. Such minions are usually no match for a hero, so they come in great numbers to counterbalance their lack of skill. Some minions are more capable. ...

They often serve as some kind of overseer or enforcer of evil and guard the mastermind's lair. Such minions are a particular challenge for a hero, but the rewards and loot for slaying them in battle are great!
I assume it is some kind of cosmic balance. When a hero slays a minion of evil the cosmic balance grants him some kind of reward. This often comes in the form of treasure. ...
Sometimes it's gold, sometimes it's a special weapon or piece of armor. Often an evil mastermind employs overseers for its hordes who guard parts of its dungeon. ...

These overseers are often in possession of high quality items that are the stuff of legend. The cosmic balance grants such items to the victorious hero so he can slay even more powerful minions of evil.

We fought many battles, with the traitors and beasts constantly on rampage at our backs. Yet we managed to deal them a crippling blow when Areak killed the creature called Bloodtooth that was leading their armies. ... But with that many casualties and enemies on all sides, we had to retreat and regroup. Do you get an idea of our problems now? ... The traitors from the Axe of Vengeance, beasts from the depths and the Lost are more than enough to cause a problem. So we can't spare any men to protect you, and if you venture into the mines you'll do it at your own risk.

agran: Areak Twobeards was probably the best fighter Kazordoon ever had, and as tough a dwarf as could be. He died after killing the Bloodtooth creature that had led the Lost. ... Though he killed the beast, he succumbed to his wounds only a few heartbeats after his enemy fell. His body was rescued and brought to Kazordoon for a proper burial.

I'm sure the gnomes could have done more when the doom blight struck us. But first they raised a quarantine to protect their own mushroom farms and later claimed that their war made it impossible to send considerably more resources. ... Still, they did something and sent resources. If their reports about their fights against enemies from below are true, then the amount of help might be deemed acceptable. ... Most importantly, they provided us with mushrooms that were resistant to the blight. I have to admit that they are more advanced in mushroom cultivation than we are. I hate to admit that we have been too caught up with traditions; it made us vulnerable.
Who cares about elves? I certainly don't!

It was like nothing we had ever seen before, and it was huge. First we thought it was some kind of war-beast, but it was frequently seen behind the lines, and rarely engaged in combat. ... Later, it became more and more obvious it was the driving force behind the attacks. Areak Twobeards led the assault that broke through the lines of the lost, and confronted the beast. ... After his death, the attacks lost in frequency, ferocity and strategic planning.

We will survive as we have countless times before. We are dwarfs and we will boldly face any challenge that fate might throw at us. ... We are more than capable to handle our affairs and even lead our people through desperate times without a doubt.

There are many creatures in the mines that came from the depths of the earth after the earthquakes. All kinds of critters are crawling, hunting and breeding in the mines now, as we had to reduce our military presence to key areas. ... Even most of the drilling rotworms have gone wild again while left unattended.

Parts of the mines are unstable or collapsed. Others are now connected to natural caves that lead to totally unknown regions of the depths. Given that this brought us the doom blight, it is hard to say what other evils might have crept into the mines.

The mines have always been an unorganized mass of tunnels, for dwarfen standards. But we follow instinct and experience when looking for promising new ore veins, and families, fellowships or trusts frequently dug in competition with each other. ... To foreigners, this may seem somewhat odd, but to us dwarfs, it seems natural and necessary.

The Thaians are an arrogant and ignorant bunch. At least they had some honour and sent some resources when the famine struck us. Still, many dwarfs lay part of the blame on humans for all that has happened.
Those Venoreans are hyenas that tried to bleed our people to death when the doom blight struck our mushroom fields. The prices and rights they demanded in exchange were outrageous. ...
Sadly, they often got their way due to the desperate situation. But on that matter, the last word has not yet been spoken, and dwarfs have a good memory.
Carlin, with its association with the elves, was never deemed trustworthy in the past. Given the strained relationship with Thais, we should perhaps reconsider this.
You can hardly call it a city. All those trees and bushes, crawling insects everywhere, and the dirt! Just the thought of it gives me shivers.

Kazordoon has seen worse times than this one in its history ... The recent earthquakes have done little harm, although combined with the threats that arose, it has been a wake-up call for certain factions; and now we are slightly changing things to be better prepared for threats and to handle certain things ... Admittedly, we have rested for too long on the accomplishments of our forefathers who had built Kazordoon. We were doing the ancestors a disservice by not adding more of our own ideas.

The big old one has seen worse earthquakes then the most recent ones. Even the mines weathered them quite well. Our mountain home shrugged them off with little notice at all. ... Legends, old even by dwarfen standards, mention earthquakes that changed the face of the surrounding lands but left the big old one unimpressed. ... It stands for protection and toughness and is more than just a home to us dwarfs, but a symbol for all that dwarfs stand and fight for. The big old one is our heart and philosophy.
We will not forget that human traders profited from the doom-blight that plagued our people. Their prices for food were an insult to all dwarfs. And for all that I heard, they tried to do worse.

After their failed rebellion, they gave up even the pretense of legitimacy. They bolster their dwindling ranks with outcasts and criminals, and rumor has it that they welcome any dwarf into their ranks, regardless of the crimes he committed.
Mh, oh? It looks like YOU WANT to help, well then...?
Dwarfs need coal for all kind of things, most prominently for blacksmithing. So coal is always rare but we need it to run that machine over there.
I hope you are willing to donate some black gold so we can get that pump pumping.
If it weren't for us dwarfs, the world would have already been overrun by monsters of all kinds.
Well, Groam is a friend. Groam and I already had that pestering pool all drained, but that didn't last long. SUDDENLY, we heard voices from down there, VOICES my friend. ...
We didn't know what to do, so we started searching the mud. AND THEN, I had that sudden urge to just leave that place. ...
PROBLEM IS, when I turned around to ask Groam about it, he just said something about an entrance and then he disappeared. ...
So my buddy already went down there, but he did not return. Eventually the water came back and the voices stopped.
I think humans are a bit whimsical but mostly they are alright.
The city is a marvel to behold and unconquered in centuries!
I don't understand the technomancers magic completely, but using coal on one of the three pumps down here will drain the water in the pool at the end of the tunnel. ...
PROBLEM IS, when the water is drained, something seems to 'awake'. ...
Hey stop looking like that, I know it's true, I don't make this up. I HEARD THEM. Alright, I heard them.
I'm Dronk Coaljuggler, Son of Fire, from the Savage Axes fellowship.

Somehow the water of the pool will return after some time, I don't know why. Maybe it has to do with 'something' down there. It makes the water rise... ah I don't know. I just want my buddy Groam to be ok.
As you might have noticed, the tunnel here is filled with water. We got the machines from the technomancers to pump the water out but our resources on coals are quite thin. ...
Most coal is used for blacksmithing and something as unimportant as an inaccessible tunnel is not deemed worthy of our black gold you know. ...
We KNOW it is no ordinary tunnel system down there though but we found some kind of ruins down there. PROBLEM IS, we had no spare time for exploring before the water drove us out. ...
Now I really would love to get the machines running but first we have to gather enough coal to make them work.
Spooky guys but they have their use, as you can see when looking at that machine over there.

The rotworm driven tunnels have to be reworked by dwarven miners before we can use them safely. They seem a bit erratic to the untrained eye but the worms are trained to dig towards the richest deposits of ore. ...
So our tunnels are exceptionally safe but sometimes even we run into problems.
Well, they are clearly... hey, wait - stop looking like that. They are there, they are talking to me. Surely you must hear them, too... clearly now... just now... or not?!
Ah by any chance, did you see... ah nothing, bye then.
I'm responsible to oversee the security and integrity of the mine tunnels. ...
Ah right, and you can help me out here if you want. PROBLEM IS, you probably don't even know what you are doing here. ...
See the pumps there? And the pool of water over there?
Good, because that is part of the problem. AND THE PROBLEM IS, while these pumps are able to drain the water out of the pond over there, they only work for a limited time. ...
They run on *coal* you see, COAL. And that's the one thing I just don't have down here right now. ...
Yeah I know that I could mine some more or just loot some creature's corpse but I can't leave just yet. ...
Still, even with that pool drained, I still need to find Groam and I surely won't leave without him.
I'm responsible to oversee the security and integrity of the mine tunnels. ...
Ah right, and you can help me out here if you want. PROBLEM IS, you probably don't even know what you are doing here. ...
See the pumps there? And the pool of water over there?
Come on. Look closer!
Hiho, hiho Player. Why do you disturb me?
I'm the foreman of this mine.
We understand the ways of the earth like nobody else.
I'm a miner, not your mother. Go ask someone else.
The hideout of the Horned Fox is probably a dangerous if not lethal place for inexperienced adventurers. It is the source of all the trouble around here.
He is a minotaur who was kicked out of Mintwallin. He must have some kind of hideout nearby.
This is not an amusement park! Leave the miners and their drilling-worms alone and get out! We've already got enough trouble without you.
Well, I could need help with that damn Horned Fox and his gang, but I guess since you are rather experienced, killing minotaurs would bore you to death. I'll wait for someone else. But thanks!
We occasionally come across nasty beasts in the deepest mines.
My name is Budrik Deepdigger, Son of Earth, from the Molten Rock.
It was very decent of you to help me, and I am thankful, really I am, but now I have to get back to my duties as a foreman.
Precisely 5:13 am, young one.
The Horned Fox is leading his bandits in sneak attacks and raids on us.
Yes, I remember him well. It was a tragedy. An earthquake led to a cave-in and many of our brave miners died. ...
Their ghosts still haunt the Grothmok tunnel in which they died, so we had to seal it off.
You may enter the tunnel.
Bye bye.
Thank the rocks! I'm so glad to have this precious heirloom back!

Mining is more than just digging in the dirt. It is an art form, a philosophy, the gathered knowledge of generations!! We Deepdiggers, Sons of Earth, from the Molten Rock have taken the science of mining to a new level!
Hi <hiccups> there, mate. I don't remember seeing your face here before. I guess your battle group has been rounded up by the imperialists and you have been sent here to join our group.
An incompetent fool like his predecessor <hiccups>. The latter even managed to have his beard stolen while sleeping, and had to resign because of that. ...

It was a member of our fellowship who managed this coup, jawoll! Even then our people were daring and worked for a change. Sadly, this lesson did not sink into the hearts of dwarfenhood as intended. ...

Or else much would have been better. A more enlightened leader and freedom for all would have prevented that stupid mushroom blight and much bloodshed. The emperor is personally responsible for the disasters in his reign. ...
The rise of foreign adventurers, the suppression of the masses, the blight and he forced us first into a rebellion, and then into exile.
<hiccups> They are single-minded despots. We just wanted a chance to live a life in wealth and glory, as they did. But they denied us that. ...

They followed ages old rules that never changed, in a society that never changed. We wanted respect <hiccups> and privileges that the elders claimed for themselves. And we wanted it now and not in hundred years or so. ...
We had enough of being bullied around by ignorants, just because their age and station gave them the right to. We <hiccups> nearly succeeded in freeing dwarfenhood and leading them to a new dawn. ...
The only thing that stopped us in the end was treason.
A true hero who has become a martyr for our cause and the dream to free dwarfenhood of oppression.
Bah, they are an even greater threat to us than the imperialists. They lack any fear and lust for blood. <hiccups> We usually try to avoid them. ...
Our attempt to lure them into the lines of the imperialists have been <hiccups> not very successful yet, but the fights between our enemies opens up a great deal of new opportunities!
<lowers his voice> There is one thing that the imperialists have always feared: ...

The basilisk! If we could get the beast to attack Kazordoon or even better, gain control over it, we could destroy the enemy forces once and for all. With the basilisk at our disposal, soon we would rule Kazordoon! ...
In the worst case it would at least wreak havoc amongst our enemies. We can certainly contain it again later on ... somehow. Our best geomancers are working on a plan right now, I tell you. ...

You know those tiny runes that allow some magic users to become the master of a creature? Now imagine, all what it takes to enslave the basilisk is probably some gibber rune and more spellcasters. ...
Soon, our days of dirt and hunger are over and we will rule over Kazordoon as we should!
Someone could not keep his mouth shut and the emperor <hiccups> got word of our plan. What should have been a clean, swift and deadly strike became a disaster. ...

Our elite just ran into a trap and was mercilessly cut down with crossbow bolts without even the chance of a fair fight. We carried the combat to the city though, but too many of the other dwarfs were not ready to be freed from the oppression. ...
They sided with the imperialists and we found ourselves outnumbered one to hundred. When we retreated to the mines, we had evened the numbers out a bit, jawoll! <hiccups> ...

But still the blood toll was too high to continue the fight in the city. So we struck the imperialists where it hurt them most - in their gold coffers! We took some of their precious mines from them! ...
And they are too afraid of us to retake them. Another sign of their weakness and incompetent leadership. They can't handle a situation that is not covered by their strict rules. <hiccups>
Good <hiccups> bye, mate.

Death will find you, too.

To get to our research missions, you need a protective layer that can be build up by harvesting the energy the monsters in the areas set free when dying.

Keep up your good work, Player.

I am the commander of the local gnomish defence force and have some missions for our Bigfoot recruits!
We gnomes are the foremost defenders against the threats of the deep. For centuries we have fought the threats from below so you surfacers are safe and can mind your own business. ...
But the threat is growing and our enemies are growing in strength and numbers too.

For your rank there are four missions available: matchmaker, golem repair, spore gathering and grindstone hunt. You can undertake each mission, but you can turn in a specific mission only once every 20 hours.
We gnomes have been hiding in the depths of the earth since the dawn of gnomehood. Still, we had our own wars and problems but relied solely on gnomish resourcefulness to survive. ...

Only recently have we had to adapt our tactics a bit since the threat is growing and more and more is at stake. If we fought only for survival and territory in the past, now our very existence and probably the fate of the entire world is at stake.
Well there are the beasties of the underworld of course. You can't imagine how many creatures are dwelling in the depths of the earth. Strange creatures of all shapes and sizes. ...

They are a threat due to their nature rather than through sinister intentions. They prey upon our mushrooms, tunnel our homes, destroy our crystals or endanger gnomish life. Then there are 'those below'. Well, that's another story entirely.
Due to your actions we have a better understanding of the operations of our enemies now. Those worm like lava creatures that are behind the global warming are our foremost foe. ...
To be precise: the foes of every living being in the world. Their machinations to heat up the world must be stopped and we must increase our war efforts even further.

Gnomish scientists have more insight into that matter than I do. But it is certainly a great danger and a real one for sure. The depths of the earth are heating up and we gnomes highly doubt that this is happening due to natural causes.
Gnomes and dwarfs profit a lot from trading.
Ah yes our foreign legion. Some gnomes have a hard time to accept that it is better to ask for some help. We might be resourceful and cunning, but even we are limited by numbers and resources. ...
Only if we all work together we can hope to survive the times to come.

Ah yes. I heard about it. It is the place where all the carrots go, when they mysteriously vanish! It has to be the carrot heaven!
I heard the blue of the sky is nothing but water. Sometimes it comes down in the form of rain drops but if it someday comes down as a whole it will drown the whole surface.
You will have to find a lonely crystal a perfect match. I don't understand the specifics but the gnomes told me that even crystals need a mate to produce offspring. ...
Be that as it may, in this package you'll find a crystal. Take it out of the package and go to the crystal caves to find it a mate. Just look out for huge red crystals and try your luck. ...
They should look like one of those seen in your soul melody test. You will find them in the crystal grounds. Report back to me when you are done.
Our gnomish crystal golems sometimes go nuts. A recent earthquake has disrupted the entire production of a golem factory. ...
I'm no expert on how those golems work, but it seems that when the crystals of the golems get out of harmony, they do as they please and even sometimes become violent. The violent ones are lost. ...

Don't bother with them, though you may decide to kill some to get rid of them. The others can be repaired, but to recall them to the workshops, the golems have to be put into a specific resonance. ...
Use the bell I gave you on the golems, so the gnomes can recall them to their workshops. Getting four of them should be enough for now. Report back when you are ready.
We gnomes want you to gather a special collection of spores. All you have to do is use a puffball mushroom and use the spore gathering kit I gave you to gather the spores. ...

There is a catch though. You need to collect different spores in a specific sequence to fill your gathering kit. If you mix the spores in the wrong way, you ruin your collection and have to start over. ...
You have to gather them in this sequence: red, green, blue and yellow. You can see on your kit what is required next.

We gnomes need some special grindstones to cut and polish specific crystals. The thing is, they can only be found in a quite dangerous lava cave full of vile monsters. You'll reach it via the hot spot teleporter. ...
It will be your task to get one such grindstone and bring it back to me.

Gnomes were secretive for the most part of their existence. Hidden deep beneath the surface we survived the countless wars and catastrophes that ravaged the world. We fought our own valiant battles though. ...
More than once gnomish society has been driven to the brink of extinction. Gnomes have fought countless battles against the beasts of the depths of the earth and races like the bone lords. ...
Secrecy, unity and ingenuity have always been the best allies of us gnomes!
Crystals and their inherent magic are the source of gnomish power. By mastering the mysteries of the crystal the gnomish society has been able to defend itself. ...
We utilize crystals, their light breaking capabilities and their resonances for a variety of purposes. ...
The gnomish transport system for instance is based upon crystals that are brought to the exactly same resonance and then charged with light to supply the energy needed for the transport.
It would take days for a gnome to make you even a bit accustomed to the wonderful world of fungi and mushrooms. There are thousands of species with hundreds of abilities and traits. ...

Crystals resonate at a certain frequency. If two crystals share the exact frequency they are bound to each other. They share not only the frequency but also other properties, ...

foremost the same place in time and space, although this might seem physically impossible to an ungnomish mind. If a user now steps on our teleport platforms and has been harmonized with the teleporter in question once, ...
then he will harmonize with the teleporter's frequency and seemingly allow him to travel from one crystal platform to its corresponding counterpart. ...
Understood? Of course you have! After all it was explained to you by a gnome!!! This gnome happens to be me by the way, just in case you didn't notice!
So are you here to become a recruit?

Excellent! I am so excited about all you big people who want to join. So you can now proceed to the recruitment office that is downstairs and that I marked on your map. But you probably need to know what this all is about first!
I hope you'll rethink this decision. Or are you already a recruit? Oh, either way, you are probably not overly interested what this is all about first.

So where to begin? Oh, I know! I am a gnome! And I am not the only one! Don't panic though, we are peaceful, I promise! Of course if I'd be evil then I'd say just the same. Oh boy, we have quite a dilemma here! ...
But let us assume that I am not evil, that is, of course I am not evil, what I mean is give me the benefit of the doubt. ...
So we are the gnomes! And we are good people! Which is quite obvious since we are small. We live underground and usually mind our own gnomish business. ...
Which is mostly about crystals and mushrooms, but that is probably not of interest for you now. Well, we are peaceful as I said, but not all underground dwellers are that peaceful, you know? ...
We handled most of them with our own resources, but recently an old, faceless enemy regained power and the threat it poses has stretched our resources so thin ...
that even things that we usually handle on a casual basis now pose a serious problem. This is where you come into play. Well that is if you become a bigfoot.
The Bigfoot company is a troop we are assembling. It is supposed to help us in our efforts to fight the threats to gnomekind.
Well, yes. We figured that you might need some human contact person. To be honest, you big ones are a bit weird sometimes and a human can handle other humans a bit better than we could. ...
So there is Commander Stone, he is the highest ranking bigfoot and he will be your contact person later on.
The underground is a dangerous place even in the best of times. These are not remotely the best of times though. ...
We fight an enormous threat that we call those below and this war drains all our resources, so that all kind of underground monsters threaten our holdings.
We don't know who the driving force is, but we encounter their warriors and bases in the underground.
Though they sometimes employ tamed monsters that are common in the underground, their foremost warriors are the lost and abominable magma creatures.
Their ancestors were probably dwarfs who became enslaved ages ago. What is left after all these years of breeding and conditioning is hardly a dwarf at all. They are murderous savages beyond compare.

They can be anything, from golems to elementals. What we know is that they are dangerous and fiercely loyal to their masters. They are magma creatures and employ a range of fiery attacks. They are strong and fearless and a great threat to us.

We have been allied with the dwarf for centuries. Our transfer of knowledge and resources has been quite low though. Sometimes we help each other out. More often than not we will ignore each other and mind our own business. ...
In the last few years though it has become more and more evident that we have common goals and common foes. This build quite strong alliances. ...
We provided the dwarfs with gnomish crystal cultivating knowledge. Only to some extent of course. ...
The dwarfs on the other hand supplied us with metal goods, armor and weapons and have of late introduced us to their allies, that is people like you. ...
That was when we decided to raise an army made up of volunteers from the outside. Something new and revolutionary in gnomish history.
Mushrooms are one of our major resources. We have cultivated and bred different forms of mushrooms for different purposes. To us they are far from being merely a food source. ...

What you call a paladin these days is a pale shadow of the paladins of old times. I expect my pupils to become role models and heroes, not selfish cowards.
Your vocation is your profession. There are four vocations in Tibia: paladins, knights, sorcerers, and druids.
Every paladin profits from his vocation. It has many advantages to be a paladin.
It might be a myth, but as long as it inspires people to great deeds, it should be retold.
If you are as old as I am, you don't care about time anymore.
Magic is a weapon like any other. If it is wielded by a fool, it can be disastrous.
I've just had dinner, but thanks.
A paladin has to be true like his aim. A good bow and a sure hand is not enough to bring down an enemy. It also takes a pure heart and an iron will.
The stories of vampires are always filled with romance and drama. I hope I live long enough to see then end of Yalahar's vampire story.
We will help you to improve your skills. Besides, I offer spells for paladins.
I'm 101 years old, but I don't consider myself as too old.
I don't even remember who was king at the time I left Thais.
Paladins are the best missile fighters in Tibia!
He seems like a fine man to me. A man that cares about his city and his people. This is something quite rare these days.
We will help you to improve your skills. Besides, I offer spells for paladins.
Paladins are great warriors and magicians. Moreover, we are excellent missile fighters. Many people in Tibia want to join us.
In a spellbook, your spells are listed. You will find the pronunciation of each spell in there. If you want to buy one, visit Xodet in the magic shop.
Of course, we aren't as strong as knights, but no druid or sorcerer will ever defeat a paladin with a sword.
Bye, Player.
My name is Lucius.
Well, I use to call myself a 'lightbearer'. I provide magical torches to light fires at places where hellish creatures are trying to enter our world, thus fending them off.
Let's not talk here. I prefer to meet you in the Temple of Light. Will you accompany me there now?
(missing answer)
Greetings, Player! We have no time to waste. Let's talk about an urgent mission.

This is the time of the year where demons try hardest to break through to our world. I try my best to keep them away by spiritually empowering those magical fire basins here in the Temple of Light. ...
However, I cannot be everywhere at the same time, and there are ten spots all over Tibia where the layer between our world and the hellish world is especially thin. ...
You need to travel to these places within a day after I gave you a magical torch. I summoned a lightbearer's basin there, similar to those here in the temple. ...
You have to use the torch on a basin to power its light. Then it will have regain enough energy to burn brightly for another two hours. ...
If you look at a basin, you can see how much energy there is still left. As long as all fire basins are burning, no creatures will be able to enter Tibia. ...
However, when only one fire basin turns dark and disappears, powerful demons will be unleashed onto this world. ...
You have to keep the fire burning for five days, and on the last day the demons will be so weakened that you can dispose of them easily when they come. ...
I can give you only one torch which lasts for a day and will then disappear. Also, you can only use your torch ONCE on each basin. ...
Thus you need to work together with your fellow Tibians, so that someone can always keep the fire basins burning, on each of the five days. ...
I can either give you the torch now - but remember it will only last for a day - or hold onto it for you until your time to be a lightbearer has come. Do you want that torch right now?
Good, then wait for a while. But don't wait too long.
Here is your torch, Player. Please try to keep all ten spots burning, and remember you can only use your torch ONCE on each spot. ...
And be careful - evil might send its minions there from time to time to keep you from lighting the basin.
There are ten of these fire basins all over Tibia. Ask me for any number between one and ten to learn more about the location where it can be found.

Those magical torches burn for much longer than normal torches. They will also protect you while you carry them. If you are willing to take on this mission, let me know.
There are ten of these fire basins all over Tibia. Ask me for any number between one and ten to learn more about the location where it can be found.
The first place might be somewhat hard to find... it is on the Formorgar Glacier on Svargrond.
The second place is in the Plains of Havoc near the Knightwatch Tower.
The third place is under the taboo area of Port Hope.
The fourth place is in the prison under Kazordoon.
The fifth place is on Ramoa, one of the Forbidden Islands close to Liberty Bay.
The sixth place is in the northern ruins of Edron, near the entrance to the demon lair.
The seventh place is deep under Drefia, at the top of the pentagram.
The eighth place is in the middle of Hellgate. It can be found close to a necromantic ritual place.
The ninth place is not very dangerous to reach. It is near Ankrahmun, in the tomb that's covered with tar pits.
The tenth place is quite close to here. Go to the area of the Magician Quarter where the earth is broken up and hellish creatures are crawling to the surface. ...
Go one level down through one of the holes and search for the fire basin in this area.
If you would like to trade any shards you might have for gold coins, just do so.
Farewell and safe journeys, Player.
What's your business here with the magicians, Player?
I can't imagine a better place to live.
Though the city has seen better days, the quality of life is still much better than in most other cities.
Hm, good question. Maybe old, wise man?
I'm used to being called old man. Simple as that.
I don't know what you're talking about.
Yes, it's a bit messy down there. Sorry.
Doesn't ring a bell.
He rarely comes here.
A man of the seas.
He used to visit me for a chat, but ever since that new tavern opened I haven't seen him much anymore.
He sometimes delivers fruit and vegetables to this quarter.
It'd be better for you to leave now.
Though the city has seen better days, the quality of life is still much better than in most other cities.
I can't imagine a better place to live
Whatever that's supposed to mean.
You can bring me a mug of tea if you want to.
Hmmm, you don't have tea with you.
Have you actually brought me a mug of tea??
What a pity.
I don't have anything that I could give you as a reward. Guess you aren't so selfless after all, huh?
They try to protect the city and do a decent job. Well - no, a poor job, I mean a poor job.
Have you actually brought me a mug of tea??
Wow. These polite young adventurers nowadays. Thank you.
Welcome to my little place, Player. How may I help you?
I'm a druid. I teach spells to other druids.
I'm known as Tamara, though my friends also nickname me Tamera.
Sorry, I don't teach spells for your vocation.
The city is dying, I can feel it. Not only in a physical sense, but also in a spiritual one.
They have lost connection to their city, to their people, to the world. They are lost.
Druids are in close communion with nature. Some of them are also close to their inner beast.
Sorcerers are very aggressive. They use their power to fight and to kill.
Their animalistic rage and their passion for battles are somewhat impressive. If they only understood the animal in them, they could gain much more power.
They restrict themselves way too much. All this talk about holiness and divine will is pointless. Still, their devotion is admirable.
Everyone who becomes a druid has the opportunity to learn many magic spells.
The breath of life is no longer blowing over this quarter. The beast of the plaque is lurking in every shady corner, and no hunter can bring it down.
A scorpion will always be a scorpion.
The pack is always looking for a leader.
The breath of life is no longer blowing over this quarter. The beast of the plaque is lurking in every shady corner, and no hunter can bring it down.
A scorpion will always be a scorpion.
The pack is always looking for a leader.
They thought they could tame magic, but magic devoured them.
The gladiators are to some extent in touch with their inner beast. Still, sometimes they are the prey rather than the predator.
It is inevitable that mother nature will claim what was once hers.
They tried to cage the forces of nature to have them work for them. Now the factories are silent and covered with dust. Those who thought to have mastered nature are gone, while nature is still here.
Eh, I haven't seen daylight for a long time. So, don't ask me, what time it is.
Another weapon of destruction. I hope nobody will ever find it.
I came here to get away from evil creatures like him, but here I've found other curses.
Thank you honey, but I pass on that offer.
He is nothing than a puppy of its uncaring masters.
Fortunately they never come here.
Oh! That cursed stone! I know about it, but I can't tell you anything. Evil gems like that shouldn't be passed around, only a crazy fool would do that.
Everyone who becomes a druid has the opportunity to learn many magic spells.
Crunor, the father of all trees, is a symbol of life.
Our members use their magic power to protect their life and the life of other creatures.
News are of little value in a city that old.
Your vocation is your profession. There are four vocations in Tibia: druids, paladins, knights, and sorcerers.
Farewell.
Hello my friend. What's up?
Guess what? I'm a thief!
People call me Jimmy Swiftfinger.
What's that? Never heard of it.
This city is a huge jail with its keepers in the middle. I've never seen its former brilliance so I rather see it in a negative light.
I don't like them and I can't see how they should ever have managed to build a city like this. I mean, they were never able to organise that many people.
Some dwarfs live in Yalahar but they are not very talkative. I have no clue where they came from.
Never heard of that.
This island is weird. It's definitely no ordinary mist that covers the island most of the days. To me it looks more like....steam from a chimney.
I've never been there because there is no reason to go. It is cold and the island is small and meagre.
We had a deal and I kept my word, so what do you want? You'd better leave now.
I don't kill people.
I was a little boy when the quarter blew up. It was a huge explosion and the stench was evil. No one made it out there alive. Every living being mutated into some monster.
What are they producing there anyway? Tell me if you find out.
I sneaked in once. You have to know that it is not allowed for 'normal' citizens like me to enter. They carry out dark experiments there, that's for sure.
No one knows what really happened there. The whole quarter is overrun with undead and demonic creatures. It's the work of the mages if you ask me.
A smart person like you has surely seen that most of the city has grown larger than the island it was built on. The Yalahari built metal construction to enlarge the city. ...
Well, in the case of the sunken quarter, it didn't work out. The whole quarter broke away and sunk into the sea.
The foreigner quarter is almost as shabby as the trade quarter. Be careful there or you might get in trouble.

I like the zoo quarter. I often go there and watch the animals. One advice, though: Stay away from the arena! The gladiators there are always up for a fight and there are rumours about some very strong undead gladiators deep down under the arena.
Ah, an adventurer. Be greeted and have a seat. How may I serve you?
Don't you know that when you know a person's name, you hold some power over that person?
Uh huh. Scary, you can read the name on my bar.
We offer bread, cheese, ham, and meat, as well as eggs and tomatoes. Ask for a trade if you want to have a look.
That's not a serious question, is it? I'm running a bar. Duh. Are you interested in my offers?
Didn't your mama teach you? Ask for a trade if you want to see what my bar has to offer.
Sure.
If you want blood, go kill a pig.
Why would you ask that? I give you a hint - don't meddle in affairs you haven't the slightest idea about.
Oh, don't talk about him. Little Mr. Know-it-all, he is.
Isn't that the fruit guy? Yes, I've seen him.
Don't see him often. He basically lives on the opposite side of the city.
He prefers to visit a nobler tavern than mine. Pff.
Isn't that the fruit guy? Yes, I've seen him.
A former pirate I think.
Fine place for me right now. Lots of... supplies.
Go away, little fly.
It'd be better for you to leave now.
This quarter might look a little run-down, but I prefer that to the shallow golden glory of the inner city.
I got beer, wine and some imported rum.
Why would I have a mission for you? Have a drink and pay for it, that's your first mission in my bar.
You know, actually I don't feel like chatting with you much. Sorry, kid.
Unimportant gofers.
He's not a bad person, even from my point of view. Lots of criminals find shelter in this quarter, which means more people who come and visit my bar.
Good bye.
Hello. What brings you here?
I guess you are here on a mission.
Yalahar is an oyster. Its treasure is waiting to be excavated by someone with the necessary determination.
He seems astonishingly determined and focused for a Yalahari. Perhaps he is the first sign of a change of wind blowing in our city. Who knows if it will be for the better.
Uhm. That cookie smells kinda strange. Don't take it as an offence, but no.
I don't care much about what has happened there. All that matters to me is that the quarter is lost and poses a danger.
In fact the arena quarter is still useful for the city. It's a good food source, and I recruit some of my best men from the descendants of the gladiators.
There are still many people living there. Of course, I provide them with some of my services as well.
It's a shame. I'm convinced there are countless treasures hidden in those ruins. However, neither bribe nor threats get my men even close to this quarter.
I wouldn't trust a single elf, let alone a whole city of them.
The word is that Thais is a dangerous place which you better do not visit unprepared.
The trade barons know how to run a city, that's for sure. Unfortunately, they are greedier than it is good for them. I'm prepared to deal with their intrusion into my territory.
Those dwarfs know how to fortify a city. Perhaps one day, when I've earned enough money and have grown too old for the trouble in Yalahar, I will retire there.
The illusion of peace that this city is offering often distracts the attention from the dangers lurking there.
He is a typical Yalahar official - always occupied with trying to stop the dam from breaking. After all these years, he still has not given up. That qualifies him either as an idealist or a fool.
All those royal bloodlines started with some kind of bandit anyhow.
Never heard of it.
The city offers great possibilities as long as order is maintained in some way. ...
It's easy to maintain order by using brute force but I see that as a necessary evil. My little empire developed out of my need for security in these times of turmoil. ...
To establish some security, I had to establish a base of power first. To maintain this power, I had to gain money somehow. ...
At this point I used my power to secure resources and to encourage trade. ...
In fact I do nothing else than the kings. I collect taxes and use them to hire men that ensure the safety of the people.
The people do their best to earn their living. Still, they are desperate. If it were not for me, they'd rob and murder each other.
Good bye.
Hello there. Wanna buy some fishing equipment? Just ask me for a trade.
Take a look.
My name is Iriana and my family lives here in Yalahar since the early days.
You can still see the brilliance of this city in its centre. It's a pity that the slow decay of the other quarters persists.
It's the domicile of the Yalahari who created this city after the God Wars. Today, the Yalahari try to let the city shine in its former brilliancy again.

The city once had 8 quarters excluding the centre. Right now you are in the former trade quarter, east of it you find the factory quarter. Further to the north-east you find the quarter known as the sunken quarter ...

followed by the magician quarter. Then you have the most northern quarter, known as the cemetery quarter, and west of that you find the former alchemist quarter. The most western quarter is the former zoo and arena quarter ...
and last but not least there is the foreigner quarter. If you want to know more about one of the single quarters, just ask me about it.
<whispers> It's all controlled by the trade baron. Stay out of his business, or you'll regret it, I promise.

Not much is known about the things going on there, or what has been produced in these factories. From time to time, the Yalahari 'appoint' inhabitants to work for them there but none of them was ever seen again.

It used to be a high society residential quarter, but as you probably realised, the city grew larger than the landmass on which it had been erected. So the quarter just broke off and sunk into the sea. That happened a very long time ago.

Nowadays, the magician quarter is the home of all magic using races. You find different races using various kinds of magic in this quarter. It can be quite dangerous there depending on which part of the quarter you enter.
Back in the days, the Yalahari caught all kinds of animals just for their own pleasure. After their disappearance, the animals escaped. They are on the loose in this quarter ever since.
In the centre of the Zoo quarter, you'll find a huge arena. Once gladiators have been battling each other to amuse the Yalahari. The most skilful of them survived and are still there.
The whole quarter is sealed up. Undead creatures took over a long time time ago. It's a mess!

I doubt that a single alchemist survived the catastrophe. There was a huge explosion which caused a chain reaction. Nowadays, it's an infested and burnt down quarter in which it is more likely to meet a mutant than a human.

The quarter west of the waterway is nowadays inhabited by various races. It used to be a residential area, but almost got completely destroyed after the downfall of Yalahar. Only the harbour promenade still contains the original buildings. ...
The other parts of the quarter have been rebuilt by the newly arrived races. For this reason, you find all those different building styles there.
I'm selling fishing equipment. You know, this isn't only the trade quarter. Most people here earn their bread and butter on the sea with a fishing rod in their hands.
I come from a family of vampire hunters, but to be honest, I'm more into the theoretic part and strategic planning.
Our nightly blood-sucking visitors put the inhabitants of Yalahar in constant danger.
A better name would be Gomorrah, if you ask me.
My name is Julius.
Storkus? Oh yes, I know him. A long time ago we used to hunt together... sometimes.
Have you brought a missing page from Marziel's diary?
Well I hope you'll find lots!
Have you brought a missing page from Marziel's diary?
I fear you don't carry any new parts of the story with you. Or, if you do, you haven't found them yourself.
It's about time you showed the vampires that they should never bother the citizens again.
I'll reward you for every pair of vampire teeth you bring me.
Another vampire raid last night. But then again, that's nothing new.
Well, I should be the one to thank you I guess.
Good bye, Player. Never trust anyone.
You are too late, flesh unit! We must restart the repair procedure.
I am a servant and maintenance golem. I also operate the lift.

If you wish to initiate the repair process ask me for repairs, male or female unit.
You must bring me the correct components or tools. The items deteriorate when they leave their conservation fields so you must be quick ...
Are you ready, flesh unit?
Grease! Grease! Procedure impossible without proper amount of grease!
I require no name.
You must bring me the correct components or tools. The items deteriorate when they leave their conservation fields so you must be quick ...

Good bye.
Welcome to Larek's private bank, Player! I can help you with your bank account or sell you parcels and the like.
My name is Kaya.
I work for the Tibian bank.
It is exactly 6:17 pm.

Larek is a member of the Explorer Society. He came here from Port Hope to explore the still little-known peninsula Krailos and I accompanied him as research assistant. I'm still a novice but proficient in Tibia's classical languages and myths. ...
That's the reason Larek asked me to assit him on this journey.

The Explorer Society is an elite society of adventurers that explore and research all aspects of our world. We are interested in the many different creatures of Tibia, as well as the history of curious structures and items.
Krailos is this peninsula that forms the northern part of Oramond. As you might have noticed it s mainly populated by ogres.
The ogres are a rough, yet interesting people. Larek has written an essay about their culture - if you want to use this word in relation to ogres. If you want to know more, feel free to ask Larek.
Many goblins are kept as slaves or are even eaten by the ogres. Unlike the dworcs or coryms who come here as stowaways at times, the goblins seem to live in Krailos for quite a while yet.

The ogres keep smaller races like goblins, dworcs or coryms as slaves. They let them do the cooking and cleaning, they send them to the mines in the south to dig up onyx and opals. Or they eat them, if they get hungry. ...
Awful, I know. I guess, we should return to Port Hope as soon as possible.

Vuzrog is the tribe's chieftain. In ogre tribes the chief is always the strongest male or - in rarer cases - female tribe member. Vuzrog is impulsive and irascible, if he's hungry. Which means ... most of the time.
The chieftain is the big boss of a tribe, as the ogres call it.
Ghorza is the tribe's shaman. She's an elder ogress who seems to have much influence here, even on the chieftain Vuzrog. She is able to exert shamanistic magic of considerable power.
An ogre shaman is the link between the tribe and the spirits.
He's one of the ogres here in the village. Some weeks ago he suddenly was very interested in Larek's doings and now he is selling and buying things, too.
I haven't seen him very often - fortunately. He seems to be cruel, blunt and disgusting even by ogre standards. ...
Most of the time he's overseeing the goblins who have to work in the faraway mines, in the mountains that seperate Krailos from southern Oramond.
Oh, the poor Nibble. He's kept as a slave by chieftain Vuzrog. He has to cook his meals, to clean his hut and so on. For a goblin he's quite cute. I really feel sorry for him.
The ogres who live in this village call themselves the Bloody Skull Tribe. They have constant clashes with the Thunder Tusk Clan.
That's a tribe of ogres living west of here. Unlike the Bloody Skull ogres they don't tolerate any visitor.
Hm, I have no idea, where this hyaena could be, I'm sorry.
Good bye.
Hello, scraggy human.
Me Ghorza.
Ghorza tribe's shaman.
Ghorza not understanding question. If sun is in sky, time is day. If sky is dark, time is night.
Great Hunger is upset. Making spirits restless. Ghorza worried about this.

Great Hunger most mighty of all spirits. Will eat up entire world if ogres not feeding it all time. So ogres give Great Hunger tasty snacks: meat, beer, humans, elves ... Great Hunger devouring everything. ...

If Great Hunger not sated it getting stomach growling. If that happening earth is quaking and trembling. Very dangerous! If ogres die, Great Hunger eating them up. In Great Hunger's stomach ogres waiting to be born again.
If ogress eating from Great Hunger's cauldron, ogress can take in little ogreling. So tribe always getting new ogres from Great Hunger's cauldron.

Cauldron is one of dried salt seas. At some times in year ogres putting in much, much food: meat, oil, roots, beer - making thick, tasty soup. Then ogres throwing in sacrifices: humans, goblins, elves ... whoever ogres get. ...
So Great Hunger is nourished. Then each younger ogress eats from cauldron. Sometimes then she taking in new ogreling waiting in cauldron.

Is new powerful spirit. Younger than Great Hunger but even more dangerous. We feeding Great Hunger with meat. Always enough meat in Krailos. Dreadful Thirst wants water, but dries up all water sources. So not enough water to calm Dreadful Thirst.

Vuzrog is Bloody Skull tribe chieftain. Is strong ogre, but getting old. Ghorza thinking, soon younger ogre will challenge Vuzrog. They will fight. If Vuzrog losing fight, Bloody Skulls having new big boss.

Vuzrog Bloody Skulls chieftain. Is big boss. Always strongest ogre is chieftain of tribe. Chieftain always mighty and brave. But if chieftain getting old, younger ogre coming, claiming chieftain tent.

Bloody Skulls are ogres living here. Biggest clan of Krailos. Other strong tribe is Thunder Tusk Clan. There other tribes, too. Having no villages but being nomadic. Take care, little human, they all maneaters.

Mhmm. Ogres eating humans, elves, dworcs and goblins. Also cow-men, if getting one. Dwarves being bit chewy and rat-men are stopgap. Not very tasty. Other tribes often eating men. But Bloody Skulls now allowing them coming here. ...

There human merchant living here. His name Larek. Knows where to get sweets like cookies or candy. If we eat him up, no more sweets. See? Sometimes benefit not to eat visitors. Perhaps you benefit, too. If not, hmmm, we'll eat you.
Thunder Tusk Clan is hostile tribe. Often battles against Thunder Tusks. They jealous. Stealing Bloody Skulls food and young ogresses. But most of all stealing water.

Shaman important for tribe. Chieftain says when fighting, where fighting and against who fighting. But shaman caring for spirits. Spirits of steppe and grassland, but also spirits of fathers and mothers. ...
Shaman also making sure that Great Hunger not getting angry.
Mugruu is ogre here in village. Friend of chieftain. Recently he buying things like human trader Larek.

He tasty little human. Came here some time ago. Wanted to stay, but Vuzrog said no. But Larek brought sweets like cookies and candy. Ogres loving sweets but not know how to make. Ghorza this told chieftain, so Vuzrog said yes. ...
Ghorza loves sweets, too, but also has other reason for deal with Vuzrog and Larek. Human knows useful things. Perhaps could be useful one day.
Female human with yellow hair. Came here with Larek.
Ah, pesky bumble! He overseeing goblins working in mines far away in high mountains. Better that way, so he not causing trouble here in village.
He little goblin. Cooking for chieftain and cleaning his tent. Useless.
Little greenlings. Weak but sometimes useful. Ogres let them getting black stones from mountains. Small tunnels there, ogres not getting in. But small goblins can. And sometimes ogres eating them.
Not know where cuddly hyaena gone. You ask other ogres in village. Perhaps they seen something.

Is name of steppe and grassland you standing in. Where suns standing most high there great mountains. We not knowing what behind. In the middle much grassland, behind that just dry soil. And behind that very, very much salty water. ...

Sometimes humans or elves coming from water. Sitting in odd wooden boxes that always breaking at stony shores. We not knowing where they from and why they using odd wooden boxes. Men calling them ships. Sometimes good food in wreckage.
Big violet flower, growing all around.
Not many dragons in Krailos. Some living in high mountains where two suns most high during day. Looking out for dragon nests there.

Little goblins getting them out of mountains for ogres. Ogres like black stones, protect against evil spirits. Many ogres got onyx chips with them. But not attack Bloody Skull Tribe ogres! Look out for hostile Thunder Tusk ogres.
Perhaps you finding some at shore or in water near shore. Ghorza seen sharks near shore many times. Or perhaps humans had some in wooden boxes. ...
Some of them carrying with them shark teeth. They saying that good for luck. Perhaps you finding some in wreckage.
Yes, Ghorza having some shamanic brew and runes for little human. Or perhaps want only brew or only runes.
You look. Also can have runes.
You look. Also can have brew.
Sea drying again, little human. You once helped filling sea. You helping again?
Not clever. Tasty little human must drink, too. (idle)
That good! You knowing what to do. Finding water spirit souls and catching in this enchanted jar.
Great Hunger peaceful now. Tasty little human done well.
Take care of evil spirits.
Hello tasty!
Me Mugruu.
Me buying things. Me watching Larek. Then me think good idea buying things.
He shrimpy human. Looking tasty. But had good idea: buying things!
Always mealtime!
Chieftain is Vuzrog. He big boss of Bloody Skull tribe.
He big boss of Bloody Skulls. That meaning chieftain.
That our tribe. Always battles against Thunder Tusks.
Hostile tribe. Try stealing food, water and women. Many battles against Bloody Skulls.
Not enough water in Krailos. Big problem.
That meaning ogre lands. Steppe and grassland. Many fat clomps, few water.
Clomp tasty beast. Much meat, very yummy!
She shaman of Bloody Skulls. Knowing many things.
Shaman is Ghorza. She always busy with spirits. And with Great Hunger.

The best fighter may be ill-suited to tend the wounds of those in need and even the most helpless person can make somebody else smile or love them, thus enriching their lives ...

The Brotherhood thinks they are free because they only pursue their own goals without morals or remorse, but they don't see they have become slaves to their greed and lost everything of importance on their way.
The community gives us hold and strength. And we give the community hold and strength in return. We don't live alone and as a community we are one ...

By caring for others we care for ourself. Not only because we might need others, too, one day but also because helping others without expecting a reward cleanses our soul from greed and selfishness ...

When our dreams tell us about the possible future they are never bright. This is why we refer to ourselves as the Nightmare Knights ...
If someone whose faith is not enough strong to overcome such seemingly overwhelming evil, he may succumb to despair or even worse might become convinced that evil is the superior force ...

A few of our members have choosen to abandon our teachings, including some we considered our most noble and wise members. Ironically, they have failed even worse on the dark side which they supposed to be so superior.
He is the enemy of all living things. He lost all humanity long ago, and that which is left is nothing but burning hatred for everyone and everything ...
Although he can be defeated, he will only truly die when he recognises the mockery his life has turned into.
Goshnar is a tragic figure. While he was one of us he tried to fight evil in such a desperate way that he never managed not live up to his own expectations ...
While trying to understand his enemy, to make out their strengthes and weaknesses he became more and more like them ...
